Package io.github.vecmatlib.vector

Interface VectorFloatOperations<F extends VectorFloatOperations<F>>

Type Parameters:
F - The same vector that implements this interface
All Superinterfaces:
VectorOperations<F>
All Known Implementing Classes:
Float2, Float3, Float4, FloatVector
public interface VectorFloatOperations<F extends VectorFloatOperations<F>> extends VectorOperations<F>
Interface that defines all base operations for any float vector.
Author:
Nico

    minus, negated, plus

  • Method Details

    • plus

      default F plus(VectorAsFloat<F> vector)
      Computes the sum of this vector with the given one.

      The sum of two vectors v1 and v2 of the same size is a vector v3 such that every i-th element of v3 is the sum of the i-th element of v1 and the i-th element of v2.

      Two vectors can only be summed if their size is the same.

      Vectors are supposed to be immutable. This means that this method does not alter the object on which it is called, it returns a new vector instead.

      Parameters:
      vector - The second operand of the sum, a vector of the same size as this one that can be represented as a float vector without casting.
      Returns:
      The sum of this vector and the given one.
      Throws:
      VectorMathException - if this vector and the given one have different sizes.
      NullPointerException - if the given vector is null.

    • minus

      default F minus(VectorAsFloat<F> vector)
      Computes the subtraction of the given vector from this one.

      The subtraction of a vector v2 from a vector v1 is defined as the sum of v1 with the additive inverse of v2. That is v1 - v2 = v1 + (-v2)

      Two vectors can only be subtracted if their size is the same.

      Vectors are supposed to be immutable. This means that this method does not alter the object on which it is called, it returns a new vector instead.

      Parameters:
      vector - The second operand of the subtraction, a vector of the same size as this one that can be represented as a float vector without casting.
      Returns:
      The sum of this vector and the additive inverse of the given one.
      Throws:
      VectorMathException - if this vector and the given one have different sizes.
      NullPointerException - if the given vector is null.

    • multipliedBy

      F multipliedBy(float k)
      Computes the multiplication between this vector and a scalar.

      The product between a vector v and a scalar k is a vector where every element i is the i-th element of v multiplied by k.

      Vectors are supposed to be immutable. This means that this method does not alter the object on which it is called, it returns a new vector instead.

      Parameters:
      k - The scalar to which this vector is multiplied.
      Returns:
      The product between this vector and the given scalar.

    • dividedBy

      default F dividedBy(float k)
      Computes the division between this vector and a scalar.

      The division of a vector v by a scalar k is defined as the multiplication between v and the multiplicative inverse 1/k. See multipliedBy(float).

      Vectors are supposed to be immutable. This means that this method does not alter the object on which it is called, it returns a new vector instead.

      Parameters:
      k - The scalar by which this vector is divided.
      Returns:
      The product between this vector and the multiplicative inverse of the given scalar.

    • dotProduct

      float dotProduct(F vector)
      Computes the dot product (or scalar product) between this vector and the given one.

      The dot product between two vectors v and w of the same size is a scalar defined as the summation of the products of every element vi and wi of the two vectors.

      The dot product can only be computed between two vectors of the same size.

      Parameters:
      vector - The second operand of the product, another float vector of the same size as this one.
      Returns:
      The result of the dot product between the two vectors.
      Throws:
      VectorMathException - if this vector and the given one have different sizes.
      NullPointerException - if the given vector is null.

    • dotProduct

      default float dotProduct(VectorAsFloat<F> vector)
      Computes the dot product (or scalar product) between this vector and the given one.

      The dot product between two vectors v and w of the same size is a scalar defined as the summation of the products of every element vi and wi of the two vectors.

      The dot product can only be computed between two vectors of the same size.

      Parameters:
      vector - The second operand of the product, a vector of the same size as this one that can be represented as a float vector without casting.
      Returns:
      The result of the dot product between the two vectors.
      Throws:
      VectorMathException - if this vector and the given one have different sizes.
      NullPointerException - if the given vector is null.

    • lengthSquared

      float lengthSquared()
      Computes the squared length (or squared magnitude) of this vector.

      When one needs to compare the length of two vectors, it is best to use this method instead of length(), since given two numbers a > b, then it also holds that a^2 > b^2, and this method is more efficient since it does not compute a square root.

      Returns:
      The squared length (or squared magnitude) of this vector.

    • length

      default double length()
      Description copied from interface: VectorOperations
      Computes the length (or magnitude) of this vector.

      The length (or magnitude) of a vector is the distance between the initial point and the endpoint of a vector, or the distance between the origin of the vector space and the vector in standard position.

      Specified by:
      length in interface VectorOperations<F extends VectorFloatOperations<F>>
      Returns:
      The length (or magnitude) of this vector.
